repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Hans Baron was a reknowned German-born historian and scholar of Italian Renaissance history and literature who emigrated from Germany in 1933. Collection includes research notes, writings, and drafts, primarily concerning the Italian Renaissance, humanism, medieval and renaissance politics, Petrarch, Machiavelli, and related topics. There are also materials regarding his most significant monographs, especially for In Search of Florentine Civic Humanism: Essays on the Transition from Medieval to Modern Thought. Papers include writings and correspondence to and from other scholars, including Ron Witt, William Bouwsma, Gene Brucker, and Paul Oskar Kristeller. The main collection has received basic processing. There are also later additions that have not been arranged: these include unsorted research and travel notes, writings, clippings, memorabilia, and correspondence. Some of these materials are related to his emigration from Germany to the United States as a Jewish refugee, and his subsequent teaching and research appointments.
did.langmaterial: Material in English, German, and Latin

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Hans Baron Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Hans Baron Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift, 1994-1995, 2002, 2008, 2012, 2015, 2016, and 2017.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Portions of this collection may not be arranged beyond the original condition. Please consult with a reference archivist before coming to use this collection.
Updated for accessions 1998-0091, 2002-0265, and 2008-0144 by Alice Poffinberger, July 2010.
Updated for accession 2012-112 by Rachel Penniman, February 2013.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Hans Baron was an influential German-born historian and scholar of Italian Renaissance history and literature. He emigrated from Germany in 1933.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Hans Baron was a reknowned German-born historian and scholar of Italian Renaissance history and literature who emigrated from Germany in 1933. Collection includes research notes, writings, and drafts, primarily concerning the Italian Renaissance, humanism, medieval and renaissance politics, Petrarch, Machiavelli, and related topics. There are also materials regarding his most significant monographs, especially for In Search of Florentine Civic Humanism: Essays on the Transition from Medieval to Modern Thought. Papers include writings and correspondence to and from other scholars, including Ron Witt, William Bouwsma, Gene Brucker, and Paul Oskar Kristeller. The main collection has received basic processing. There are also later additions that have not been arranged: these include unsorted research and travel notes, writings, clippings, memorabilia, and correspondence. Some of these materials are related to his emigration from Germany to the United States as a Jewish refugee, and his subsequent teaching and research appointments.

Addition (02-265)(200 items, 0.4 lin. ft.; dated 1928-1971 and undated) contains research notes and materials relating to Francesco da Fiano, a 15th century Italian humanist. Also includes a packet of correspondence between Gene Brucker and Baron (1961-1971).

Addition (08-144)(45 items, .1 lin. ft.; dated 1971-1988) primarily contains correspondence between Baron and Ronald Witt (Duke University) regarding their publications and research, including grants for release time and negotiations with publishers; their agreements and disagreements regarding their area of specialization; and the problems associated with teaching at the college level in their specialty. Includes a few addendums to letters written by Baron's wife, Edith, as well as two letters to Witt from other sources. A few of the letters are missing pages.
Addition (2012-112) (0.8 lin. ft., 600 items) includes notes and edited drafts related to Hans Baron's work on Leonardo Bruni.

Addition (2015-0108) (2.0 lin. ft.) includes academic and personal correspondence, as well as other research and teaching materials, offficial emigration documents, travel notes, with a few memorabilia, and clippings, largely dating from the mid-1920s-1960s.
Addition (2017-0111) (1.0 lin. ft.) includes manuscript drafts, correspondence, and reproductions regarding Poggio Florentini.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Materials have been boxed as received and, for the most part, original file folder titles have been retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Addition (98-091) (17 items, .1 lin. ft.; dated 1954-1986) contains primarily letters to Baron regarding publications in his specialty, and well as his notes on pulications and letters to authors. This material is housed with Acc. 2008-0144 (Box 1).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Addition (02-265) (200 items, .4 lin. ft.; dated 1928-1971) contains research notes and materials relating to Francesco da Fiano, a 15th century Italian humanist. Also includes a packet of correspondence between Gene Brucker and Baron (1961-1971).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Addition (08-144) (45 items, .1 lin. ft.; dated 1971-1988) primarily contains correspondence between Baron and Ronald Witt regarding their publications and research, including grants for release time and negotiations with publishers; their agreements and disagreements regarding their area of specialization; and the problems associated with teaching at the college level in their specialty. Includes a few addendums to letters written by Baron's wife, Edith, as well as two letters to Witt from other sources. A few of the letters are missing pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Addition (2012-112) (0.8 lin. ft., 600 items) includes notes and edited drafts related to Hans Baron's work on Leonardo Bruni.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal and academic correspondence and other papers, largely dating from the 1930s and 1940s, written in English and German. Correspondence includes telegrams, manuscript letters, and typescripts, and has been loosely arranged by year.

did.unittitle: Research, Teaching, Travel, Notes, and Official Documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with the "Notgemeinschaft deutscher Wissenschaftler im Ausland" (Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced Foreign Scholars), Applications to Swiss Universities, and documents regarding "Umhabilitierung" (licensing to teach as a tenured professor in Switzerland).

did.unittitle: Italy (Florence, Rome, Turin, Bologna, Milan, Padua, Venice, Pisa)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File of correspondence from scholars and acquaintances, receipts, and many notes includes a 9-page bundle of travel notes in German, written while in Rome and dated July 1925, expressing the happiness of the period he spent in Florence, and comparing Florentine culture, art and architecture, and historical sites to those of Rome (accession 2016-0218). Three dots prefacing these notes appear to be a continuation of another travel essay.

did.unittitle: Italy and Notgemeinschaft der deutschen Wissenschaft (Emergency Association of German Science)
Expenses for the Historical Commission Munich

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes inventory list of household items and Baron's personal library.

did.unittitle: Grant Applications to Guggenheim Foundation and American Philosophical Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes school report cards, high school graduation certificate (Reifezeugnis), univerity diplomas, marriage license, birth certificate, genealogical documents, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes newspaper clippings, single articles, bank statements, various receipts, notes on (mainly American) scholars, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes ID cards, high school graduation certificate (Reifezeugnis), univerity diplomas, dissertation documents, articles by Edith Baron, some letters, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the letters from 1867-1869 are signed by a David and sent from Breslau (Wroclav).

did.unittitle: Jewish Economic Aid, Oldenbourg Pusblishing House, German CVs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Friedrich Meinecke (Berlin) and the publishing house Oldenbourg regarding the referral of a contribution to a handbook on the Renaissance to Prof. Goetz and future carreer plans.
